article:
This is a partial list of known or supposed Hungarian loanwords in English:

; biro : From [[LÃ¡szlÃ³ BÃ­rÃ³]], the Hungarian inventor of the ballpoint
pen. [[Oxford English Dictionary]], s.v. "biro". BÃ­rÃ³ originally means
judge. ; coach : From kocsi, a horseâdrawn wagon with springs above the axles.
Named after the village of Kocs in which this type of vehicle was invented. The
verb 'to coach' is also derived from this root. [[Oxford English
Dictionary]], s.v. "coach". ; czardas : From csÃ¡rdÃ¡s, a Hungarian folk
dance. CsÃ¡rda also means 'tavern'. ; Dobos torte or Dobosh : From Dobos torta,
"Dobos cake". After confectioner JÃ³zsef C. Dobos. ; friska: From friss, a fast
section of music, often associated with czardas dances (cf. lassan). ; goulash :
From gulyÃ¡s, a type of stew known in Hungarian as gulyÃ¡s in Hungary,
'gulyÃ¡s'levesis a soup dish; leves meaning soup. [[GulyÃ¡s (herdsman)|GulyÃ¡s]]
also means 'herdsman' dealing with cattle, as the noungulyais the Hungarian word
for cattle herd. (This can cause confusion with native Hungarian speakers, as
Hungarians generally understand unqualified "gulyÃ¡s" to mean "gulyÃ¡sleves", the
soup, instead referring to the internationalgoulash'' as "pÃ¶rkÃ¶lt".) ; hajduk:
From hajdÃºk, "bandits". Outlaw, guerilla fighter. The original Hungarian meaning
was "cattle drover". ; halÃ¡szlÃ©:, or Fisherman's Soup, a very hot and spicy
river fish soup with a lot of paprika. (The actual Hungarian halÃ¡szlÃ© is not
always made with hot paprika, unlike the internationally-known soup.) ; hussar :
From Hungarian huszÃ¡r, a light cavalry soldier. The Hungarian word originally
meant "freebooter" and was further derived via Old Serbian husar, gusar, gursar
("pirate") from Italian corsaro ("pirate"), i.e. the same root as that of
English [[Privateer|corsair]]. ''Oxford English Dictionary, s.v.
"hussar". ; : is sometimes linked to Hungarian ici-pici ("tiny") by
popular sources, GyÃ¶rgy TÃ­mÃ¡r, [http://www.lib.jgytf.u-
szeged.hu/folyoiratok/edes_anyanyelvunk/9903e.htm Magyar eredetÅ± idegen szavak /
foreign words of Hungarian origin], Ãdes AnyanyelvÃ¼nk (Our Loved Vernacular)
Magazine, 3. 1999. Oksana Buranbaeva, Vanja
Mladineo, [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=WK_130Hqbr4C&pg=PA59&dq=itsy-
bitsy+hungarian+word&hl=en&sa=X&ei=i2hmT5OSFILb8AOMyYy5CA&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA#v=one-
page&q=itsy-bitsy%20hungarian%20word&f=false Culture and Customs of Hungary],
ABC-CLIO, 2011, p. 59 Richard S. Esbenshade, Hungary, M. Cavendish,
1994. p. 77 but is regarded as an unrelated English formation by English
dictionaries. [[Oxford English Dictionary]], s.v. "itsy-bitsy"; Oxford
Dictionary of English (2005), s.v. "itsy-bitsy"; Online Etymological Dictionary
[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=itsy-
bitsy]. ; komondor : A big Hungarian breed of livestock guardian and dog,
looking like big mop, always white. ; kuvasz : A big Hungarian breed of shepherd
dog, always white. ; lassan: From lassÃº, "slowly". a slow section of music,
often associated with czardas dances (cf. friska). ; palacsinta : a form of
pancake popular throughout central Europe ; puli : A small Hungarian breed of
shepherd dog, also looking like a mop, usually black or white. ; sabre (UK) or
saber (US): From French (sabre, sable), ultimately from an unknown source in a
language of Eastern origin, possibly through Hungarian szablya,
backsword. ''Oxford English Dictionary, s.v. "sabre". ; shako or tsako
: From csÃ¡kÃ³ sÃ¼veg, 'peaked cap', a stiff military hat with a high crown and
plume. [[Oxford English Dictionary]], s.v. "shako". ; tokaji or tokay
: From tokaji aszÃº, the name of the wine from Tokaj, the centre of the local wine-
growing district Tokaj-Hegyalja. ; verbunkos : a
Hungarian men's folk dance and musical style (itself coming from German -
meaning "military recruitment" here). ; vizsla or vizla: From vizsla, a
Hungarian breed of hunting dog.
